title: How to Make Chocolate Body Paint

steps.headline: Place the sugar, salt and water into the saucepan.
Heat over medium heat.
steps.description: Heat until it start to boil, then lower to a simmer. Do not stir the ingredients.

steps.headline: Remove the mixture from the heat when the sugar has dissolved.
Tip in the cocoa powder, vanilla and chocolate extract or essence.
steps.description: If you are using alcohol, add it now. It might be nice to use crème de cacao or a similar chocolatey liqueur.

steps.headline: Whisk well.
steps.description: Don't be surprised to see lumps forming, just keep whisking them out. The chocolate paint is ready when it turns smooth and has a silky texture. You can spread it on a wooden spoon to test if it's done––it will form a thick, smooth coat on the spoon.

steps.headline: Transfer the mixture into the glass container.
steps.description: If you wanted a decorated container, do this beforehand. Add a label if you like, with a fun message on it perhaps, such as "chocolatey love potion".

steps.headline: Wait until the chocolate paint has cooled down sufficiently.
steps.description: If you're unsure, test a small amount on your forearm. The paint can burn your skin if used before it has cooled sufficiently.

steps.headline: Use a pastry brush to paint the chocolate onto skin.
steps.description: Where you paint it is your business.

steps.headline: Reheat to restore the thinner paint-like state.
steps.description: If the chocolate body paint thickens or has been refrigerated, reheat in a microwave or a double boiler. As with before, if you do this, be sure it is cool enough before using.

text: Making the chocolate body paint Place the sugar, salt and water into the saucepan.  Heat over medium heat. Heat until it start to boil, then lower to a simmer. Do not stir the ingredients. Remove the mixture from the heat when the sugar has dissolved.  Add the butter cubes. Whisk until combined. Tip in the cocoa powder, vanilla and chocolate extract or essence. If you are using alcohol, add it now. It might be nice to use crème de cacao or a similar chocolatey liqueur. Whisk well. Don't be surprised to see lumps forming, just keep whisking them out. The chocolate paint is ready when it turns smooth and has a silky texture. You can spread it on a wooden spoon to test if it's done––it will form a thick, smooth coat on the spoon. Transfer the mixture into the glass container. If you wanted a decorated container, do this beforehand. Add a label if you like, with a fun message on it perhaps, such as "chocolatey love potion". Using the chocolate paint Wait until the chocolate paint has cooled down sufficiently. If you're unsure, test a small amount on your forearm. The paint can burn your skin if used before it has cooled sufficiently. Use a pastry brush to paint the chocolate onto skin. Where you paint it is your business. Reheat to restore the thinner paint-like state. If the chocolate body paint thickens or has been refrigerated, reheat in a microwave or a double boiler. As with before, if you do this, be sure it is cool enough before using.
